perturbation.original_text:
2.2 The seller shall be confirmed within three working days after receipt of order. If the seller finds order is not acceptable or need to modify, should
note entrusted party in two working days after receipt of the order, If the seller did not confirm orders in time or notice not accept orders or
modifications, the seller is deemed to have been accepted the order. The orders become effective once the seller accepts, any party shall not
unilaterally cancel the order before the two sides agreed .
perturbation.changed_text: 2.2 The seller shall endeavor to confirm within three working days after receipt of order. If the seller finds order is not acceptable or need to modify, should note entrusted party in two working days after receipt of the order, If the seller did not confirm orders in time or notice not accept orders or modifications, the seller is deemed to have been accepted the order. The orders become effective once the seller confirms, but either party may cancel the order with a 30-day written notice prior to the scheduled delivery date.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that the seller *shall* confirm within three days, implying a strict obligation. The modified text changes 'shall' to 'endeavor to,' weakening this obligation. Furthermore, the original text strictly prohibits unilateral cancellation after acceptance, while the modified text allows cancellation with 30 days' notice. This creates a contradiction regarding the binding nature of accepted orders.

perturbation.original_text:
15. GUARANTEE OF QUALITY: The Sellers guarantee that the commodity hereof is complies in all respects with the quality and specification
stipulated in this Contract.
perturbation.changed_text: 15. GUARANTEE OF QUALITY: The Sellers guarantee that the commodity hereof generally complies with the quality and specification stipulated in this Contract.
perturbation.explanation: The original text offers an absolute guarantee of compliance. The modification inserts 'generally complies,' introducing ambiguity. This creates a contradiction if other clauses rely on the commodity meeting specific and exact specifications.

perturbation.original_text:
16. CLAIMS: Within 7 days after the arrival of the goods at destination, should the quality, specification, or quantity be found not in conformity
with the stipulations of the Contract except those claims for which the insurance company or the owners of the vessel are liable, the Buyers, on the
strength of the Inspection Certificate issued by the China Commodity Inspection Bureau, have the right to claim for replacement with new goods, or
for compensation, and all the expenses (such as inspection charges, freight for returning the goods and for sending the replacement, insurance
premium, storage and loading and unloading charges etc.) shall be borne by the Sellers.
The Certificate so issued shall be accepted as the base of a claim. The Sellers, in accordance with the Buyers’ claim, shall be responsible for the
immediate elimination of the defect(s), complete or partial replacement of the commodity or shall devaluate the commodity according to the state of
defect(s). Where necessary, the Buyers shall be at liberty to eliminate the defect(s) themselves at the Sellers’ expenses. If the Sellers fail to answer
the Buyers within one weeks after receipt of the aforesaid claim, the claim shall be reckoned as having been accepted by the Sellers.
perturbation.changed_text: 16. CLAIMS: Within 7 days after the arrival of the goods at destination, should the quality, specification, or quantity be found not in conformity with the stipulations of the Contract except those claims for which the insurance company or the owners of the vessel are liable, the Buyers, on the strength of the Inspection Certificate issued by the China Commodity Inspection Bureau, may attempt to claim for replacement with new goods, or for compensation. The Buyers may issue the claim and the certificate so issued by the China Commodity Inspection Bureau, but it will be in Seller’s sole discretion to accept it as the base of a claim. The Sellers, in accordance with their internal policies and procedures and at their own discretion, may determine if the defect(s) will be eliminated, the commodity will be replaced or devaluated. The buyers are not allowed to eliminate the defect(s) themselves at the Sellers’ expenses. If the Sellers fail to answer the Buyers within one weeks after receipt of the aforesaid claim, it does not automatically mean that the claim shall be reckoned as having been accepted by the Sellers.
perturbation.explanation: The original text grants the buyer a *right to claim* and mandates that the inspection certificate *shall be accepted* as the basis of a claim, placing a firm obligation on the seller. The changed text weakens the buyer's position considerably, stating that the buyer *may attempt to claim* and grants the seller the *sole discretion* to accept the certificate. Further, the 'shall' regarding remedies like defect elimination is changed to a discretionary 'may determine if', and the final sentence removes the automatic acceptance of a claim if the seller doesn't respond, contradicting the original text's clear timeline.
